results.text: You overlook a source of danger, thinking it’s nothing. The party experiences an environment-dependent penalty or hazard (Adventurer’s Guide, page 452), as determined by the Narrator.
You lose the trail of a creature you are currently tracking. For the next hour, you cannot pick up the tracks of the target except by magical means.

You stepped in something (such as grease, mud, or some other substance) that leaves visible tracks. Creatures have advantage on any sight-based checks made to track you and your allies for the next hour.
Everything is starting to look the same to you—did you pass that landmark once already? You lose a day of travel as you struggle to get back on the path.

The taxing hike has taken so much out of you, you don’t realize that you’ve dropped something while on your journey until you stop for the night. You lose one piece of small, mundane adventuring gear, as determined by the Narrator.

You accidentally mistake poisonous plants, fungi, or insects for the edible kind while foraging. The next time you and your allies roll initiative, a character of the Narrator’s choosing is poisoned at the start of their turn. They remain poisoned until either they succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC 15) or three rounds have passed, whichever comes first.
